appeal-to-fear.name: Appeal to Fear
appeal-to-fear.definition: Using fear or threat of negative consequences to persuade rather than logical reasoning.
appeal-to-fear.learningTip: Ask: 'Is this argument based on evidence or trying to scare me into action?'

slippery-slope.name: Slippery Slope
slippery-slope.definition: Arguing that one event will inevitably lead to a chain of negative consequences without evidence.
slippery-slope.learningTip: Look for: 'If we do X, then Y will happen, then Z will happen...' without proof.

false-dilemma.name: False Dilemma
false-dilemma.definition: Presenting only two options when more alternatives exist.
false-dilemma.learningTip: Ask: 'Are there really only these two choices, or are there other options?'

post-hoc.name: Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc
post-hoc.shortName: After This, Therefore Because of This
post-hoc.definition: Assuming that because one thing follows another, the first caused the second.
post-hoc.learningTip: Remember: Correlation doesn't equal causation. Just because A happened before B doesn't mean A caused B.

ad-hominem.name: Ad Hominem
ad-hominem.definition: Attacking the person making an argument rather than addressing the argument itself.
ad-hominem.learningTip: Focus on the argument, not the person. Character attacks usually mean weak reasoning.

hasty-generalization.name: Hasty Generalization
hasty-generalization.definition: Drawing broad conclusions from limited examples or small sample sizes.
hasty-generalization.learningTip: Ask: 'Is this sample size large enough to support such a broad conclusion?'

appeal-to-tradition.name: Appeal to Tradition
appeal-to-tradition.definition: Arguing something is correct because it's traditional or has been done for a long time.
appeal-to-tradition.learningTip: 'We've always done it this way' isn't proof that it's the best way.

false-scarcity.name: False Scarcity
false-scarcity.definition: Creating artificial time pressure or limited availability to force quick decisions.
false-scarcity.learningTip: Real scarcity provides specific, verifiable details. Fake scarcity uses vague pressure.

cherry-picking.name: Cherry Picking
cherry-picking.definition: Selecting only evidence that supports your conclusion while ignoring contradictory evidence.
cherry-picking.learningTip: Look for the full picture. What evidence are they NOT showing you?

appeal-to-authority.name: Appeal to Authority
appeal-to-authority.definition: Using someone's credentials or status as proof, regardless of their expertise in the specific topic.
appeal-to-authority.learningTip: Ask: 'Is this person actually qualified in this specific area?'

straw-man.name: Straw Man
straw-man.definition: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
straw-man.learningTip: Ask: 'Is this really what they said, or a twisted version of it?'

bandwagon.name: Bandwagon Fallacy
bandwagon.definition: Arguing something is correct because many people believe it or do it.
bandwagon.learningTip: Popularity doesn't equal truth. Many people can be wrong about something.

red-herring.name: Red Herring
red-herring.definition: Introducing irrelevant information to distract from the main argument.
red-herring.learningTip: Ask: 'How does this relate to the original question or argument?'

appeal-to-nature.name: Appeal to Nature
appeal-to-nature.definition: Arguing that something is good because it's natural or bad because it's artificial.
appeal-to-nature.learningTip: Natural doesn't automatically mean safe or good. Poison ivy is natural too.

false-equivalence.name: False Equivalence
false-equivalence.definition: Treating two very different things as if they're equivalent or equally valid.
false-equivalence.learningTip: Not all opinions or positions are equally valid. Some have more evidence than others.
